node.title: Michelle Wu is the first woman and first person of color to be elected mayor of Boston.
node.description: “We are ready to be a Boston for everyone,” said Ms. Wu, whose campaign was buoyed by support from the city’s young, left-leaning voters and by Black, Asian and Latino residents.
node.content: ["BOSTON \u2014 Michelle Wu, who entered public service out of frustration with the obstacles that her immigrant family faced, will be the next mayor of Boston, pledging to make the city a proving ground for progressive policy.", "Buoyed by support from the city\u2019s young, left-leaning voters and by Black, Asian and Latino residents, Ms. Wu, 36, soundly defeated City Councilor Annissa Essaibi George.", "Ms. Essaibi George, who ran as a pragmatic centrist in the style of former Mayor Martin J. Walsh, had the backing of the city\u2019s traditional power centers, like its police, its trade unions and its working-class Irish American neighborhoods.", "\u201cFrom every corner of our city, Boston has spoken,\u201d Ms. Wu said, to a jubilant crowd in the city\u2019s South End. \u201cWe are ready to meet the moment. We are ready to be a Boston for everyone.\u201d", "Conceding the race, Ms. Essaibi George said, \u201cI want to offer a great big congratulations to Michelle Wu.\u201d", "\u201cShe is the first woman, first person of color, and as an Asian American, the first elected to be mayor of Boston,\u201d she said. \u201cI know this is no small feat.\u201d", "Ms. Wu \u2014 who grew up outside Chicago and moved to the Boston area to attend Harvard \u2014 was an unusual candidate for this city, and her victory sets a number of precedents.", "She is the first woman and the first person of color to be elected mayor in Boston, which has been led by an unbroken string of Irish American or Italian American men since the 1930s. Kim Janey, a Black woman, has served as acting mayor since March, when Mr. Walsh was confirmed as the U.S. labor secretary. Ms. Wu will also be the first mayor of Boston not born in the city since 1925.", "Boston has been booming, as jobs in technology, medicine and education attract waves of young professionals. But that success has come at a cost, forcing working-class and middle-class families to leave the city in search of affordable housing.", "Ms. Wu has promised to push back against gentrification, with policies tailored to help lower-income residents stay in the city, such as waiving fees for public transport, imposing a form of rent control, and reapportioning city contracts to firms owned by Black Bostonians.", ""]
